Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2010 01:35AM Jo_in_California wrote: So sorry to hear about your situation, Joanna (BTW, that's also my name, born in 1969 as well, and having an excisional biopsy on December 2nd, too).  Have you called the breast surgeon about the new lumps?  Though Dec 2 is pretty close, it can't hurt to call them; maybe they can get you in a bit earlier.  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: Mamo, Ultrasound, and next the BS joanna69 leaf

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2010 06:34PM Jo_in_California wrote: Kathleen, Wishing you lots of good thoughts right now. It's easy to feel down during the holidays, and if you have kids, I think it really makes you think darker thoughts like, "How many Christmases do I have left?"  Just know that the holiday season will soon be over, the days will start getting longer, and the sun will start shining more brightly. I am so sorry you are feeling so all alone.  Just know that there are many of us feeling the same way right now...not sure if that's much consolation, but you are not alone. Agree with the OP that you need to find a more positive place to get treatment.  It's not right for them to allow an chemo room to feel drab or depressing.  Let them know why you're leaving if you do decide to leave for another place.  They need to know how the conditions are making their patients feel. Best of luck, and I hope your treatment goes very well!

Posts.Title: Microcalcifications & ALH - HELP!! Rshep9101 Rshep9101

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2010 02:35AM Jo_in_California wrote: Definitely agree with hollybee.  You should pursue it until someone gives you a definitive diagnosis.  If they can feel it, they can biopsy it.  There are too many stories of people whose cancers didn't show up with various imaging tests.  Imaging is just one way to detect cancer.  If a palpable finding doesn't show up with U/S, mammo, MRI, etc.; it still should be biopsied, IMHO. Best of luck to you!
